speaker: him
text: Brother Ferrier,

speaker: his
text: the true believers have been good friends to you. We picked you up when you were starving in the desert, we shared our food with you, led you safe to the Chosen Valley, gave you a goodly share of land, and allowed you to wax rich under our protection. Is not this so?

speaker: John Ferrier
text: It is so,

speaker: Ferrier
text: In return for all this we asked but one condition: that was, that you should embrace the true faith, and conform in every way to its usages. This you promised to do, and this, if common report says truly, you have neglected.

speaker: Ferrier
text: And how have I neglected it?

speaker: Ferrier
text: Have I not given to the common fund? Have I not attended at the Temple? Have I not--?

speaker: Young
text: Where are your wives?

speaker: Young
text: Call them in, that I may greet them.

speaker: Ferrier
text: It is true that I have not married,

speaker: John Ferrier
text: But women were few, and there were many who had better claims than I. I was not a lonely man: I had my daughter to attend to my wants.

speaker: John Ferrier
text: It is of that daughter that I would speak to you,

speaker: John Ferrier
text: She has grown to be the flower of Utah, and has found favour in the eyes of many who are high in the land.

speaker: John Ferrier
text: There are stories of her which I would fain disbelieve--stories that she is sealed to some Gentile. This must be the gossip of idle tongues. What is the thirteenth rule in the code of the sainted Joseph Smith? 'Let every maiden of the true faith marry one of the elect; for if she wed a Gentile, she commits a grievous sin.' This being so, it is impossible that you, who profess the holy creed, should suffer your daughter to violate it.

speaker: Ferrier
text: Upon this one point your whole faith shall be tested--so it has been decided in the Sacred Council of Four. The girl is young, and we would not have her wed grey hairs, neither would we deprive her of all choice. We Elders have many heifers*1, but our children must also be provided. Stangerson has a son, and Drebber has a son, and either of them would gladly welcome your daughter to their house. Let her choose between them. They are young and rich, and of the true faith. What say you to that?

speaker: her
text: You will give us time,

speaker: Unknown
text: My daughter is very young--she is scarce of an age to marry.

speaker: Young
text: She shall have a month to choose,

speaker: her
text: At the end of that time she shall give her answer.

speaker: Unknown
text: It were better for you, John Ferrier,

speaker: her
text: that you and she were now lying blanched skeletons upon the Sierra Blanco, than that you should put your weak wills against the orders of the Holy Four!

speaker: Unknown
text: I could not help it,

speaker: his
text: His voice rang through the house. Oh, father, father, what shall we do?

speaker: His
text: Don't you scare yourself,

speaker: her
text: We'll fix it up somehow or another. You don't find your fancy kind o' lessening for this chap, do you?

speaker: Lucy
text: No; of course not. I shouldn't care to hear you say you did. He's a likely lad, and he's a Christian, which is more than these folk here, in spite o' all their praying and preaching. There's a party starting for Nevada to-morrow, and I'll manage to send him a message letting him know the hole we are in. If I know anything o' that young man, he'll be back here with a speed that would whip electro-telegraphs.

speaker: Lucy
text: When he comes, he will advise us for the best. But it is for you that I am frightened, dear. One hears--one hears such dreadful stories about those who oppose the Prophet: something terrible always happens to them.

speaker: Lucy
text: But we haven't opposed him yet,

speaker: Lucy
text: It will be time to look out for squalls when we do. We have a clear month before us; at the end of that, I guess we had best shin out of Utah.

speaker: Lucy
text: Leave Utah!

speaker: Lucy
text: That's about the size of it.

speaker: Lucy
text: But the farm?

speaker: Lucy
text: We will raise as much as we can in money, and let the rest go. To tell the truth, Lucy, it isn't the first time I have thought of doing it. I don't care about knuckling under to any man, as these folk do to their darned prophet. I'm a free-born American, and it's all new to me. Guess I'm too old to learn. If he comes browsing about this farm, he might chance to run up against a charge of buckshot travelling in the opposite direction.

speaker: Lucy
text: But they won't let us leave,

speaker: John Ferrier
text: Wait till Jefferson comes, and we'll soon manage that. In the meantime, don't you fret yourself, my dearie, and don't get your eyes swelled up, else he'll be walking into me when he sees you. There's nothing to be afeared about, and there's no danger at all.
